*The Er’ya of Alchemical Minerals*

**Title:** *The Er’ya of Alchemical Minerals*. Compiled by Mei Biao of the Tang. One fascicle. Base text from *The Orthodox Daoist Canon*, "Wondrous Arts" category of the *Dongshen* section.

**Preface to *The Er’ya of Alchemical Minerals***
The *Er’ya* was composed by the ancients to explicate and resolve what was difficult to seek. I have always marveled at its ingenious and unparalleled mechanism. Thus, it has been employed by the court and endured through many ages. I am from Jiangyuan in western Shu. From youth, I was fond of the Dao and its arts, my nature inclined toward elixir techniques. From my tender years to the age of knowing fate, I exhaustively studied the classics and formulas, having perused the works of hundreds of masters—all as clear as the lines on my palm. Yet the ingredients they used were all concealed by hidden names. Within these hidden names, moreover, there were many variants. Without comprehensive knowledge, one might as well chase painted cakes or dreamt peaches; encountering their formulas would be no different from never having encountered them at all. I have often sighed in frustration over this matter, lamenting the absence of a teacher—what recourse is there?

I once read in the *Cantong Qi*: "If one cannot fully investigate, one should provide straightforward explanations—thus is the principle exhausted." The classic states: "I wished to seal my tongue and speak not, fearing the crime of execution; yet to inscribe my thoughts on bamboo and silk would risk leaking the celestial tally." Thus do we know that the sagely and perfect Dao, the mysterious and wondrous method, is not meant for the vulgar—only by chance might it be heard and understood. Therefore, the matter is presented in a roundabout manner, so that superior scholars may diligently study it, while inferior scholars may discard and ridicule it—such is the evident principle.

Yet I fear that later learners may share my hardships. Thus, I have appended the oral instructions of six schools and the alternative names of various minerals, modeling the phrasing after the *Er’ya*. In six sections, I have compiled them into one fascicle, so that those lost in confusion may find it somewhat easier to seek, and those practicing the art may recite it without difficulty. I have also included all the alternative names for ingredients used in various elixirs, listing the designations of extraordinary formulas and rare safeguards that possess methods for preparation at the forefront, while those without methods or difficult to produce are recorded afterward.

Written in the *bingxu* year of the Yuanhe era of the Tang by Mei Biao.

chunks.original_text: 石药尔雅 经名：石药尔雅。 唐梅彪撰。 一卷。 底本出处：《正统道藏》洞神部众术类。 石药尔雅序 夫尔雅者，古人以训释难寻之所作也。 每想此机捷妙无以加。 故朝廷用之，兼经多历年代。 余西蜀江源人也。 少好道艺，性攻丹术，自弱至于知命，穷究经方，曾览数百家论功者，如同指掌，用药皆是隐名。 就於隐名之中，又有多本。 若不备见，犹画饼梦桃，遇其经方，与不遇无别。 每噫嗟此事怅恨，无师由何意也。 因见《参同契》云：未能悉究，当施直义，其理尽矣。 经曰：吾欲结舌不言，恐畏获罪诛，写情於竹帛，恐泄天之符。 故知圣贤至道，玄妙之法，不欲流俗，偶然之所闻解也。 故委曲其事，令上士勤而习之，使下士弃而笑之，理昭然也。 但恐后学同余苦心，今附六家之口诀，众石之异名，象《尔雅》词句，凡六篇，勒为一卷，令疑迷者寻之稍易，习业者诵之不难。 兼诸丹所有别名。 奇方异卫之号，有法可营造者，条列於前。 无法难作之流，具名於后。 时唐元和丙戌梅彪序。 石药尔雅卷上 梅彪集

*The Er’ya of Alchemical Minerals*

**Title:** *The Er’ya of Alchemical Minerals*. Compiled by Mei Biao of the Tang. One fascicle. Base text from *The Orthodox Daoist Canon*, "Wondrous Arts" category of the *Dongshen* section.

**Preface to *The Er’ya of Alchemical Minerals***
The *Er’ya* was composed by the ancients to explicate and resolve what was difficult to seek. I have always marveled at its ingenious and unparalleled mechanism. Thus, it has been employed by the court and endured through many ages. I am from Jiangyuan in western Shu. From youth, I was fond of the Dao and its arts, my nature inclined toward elixir techniques. From my tender years to the age of knowing fate, I exhaustively studied the classics and formulas, having perused the works of hundreds of masters—all as clear as the lines on my palm. Yet the ingredients they used were all concealed by hidden names. Within these hidden names, moreover, there were many variants. Without comprehensive knowledge, one might as well chase painted cakes or dreamt peaches; encountering their formulas would be no different from never having encountered them at all. I have often sighed in frustration over this matter, lamenting the absence of a teacher—what recourse is there?

I once read in the *Cantong Qi*: "If one cannot fully investigate, one should provide straightforward explanations—thus is the principle exhausted." The classic states: "I wished to seal my tongue and speak not, fearing the crime of execution; yet to inscribe my thoughts on bamboo and silk would risk leaking the celestial tally." Thus do we know that the sagely and perfect Dao, the mysterious and wondrous method, is not meant for the vulgar—only by chance might it be heard and understood. Therefore, the matter is presented in a roundabout manner, so that superior scholars may diligently study it, while inferior scholars may discard and ridicule it—such is the evident principle.

Yet I fear that later learners may share my hardships. Thus, I have appended the oral instructions of six schools and the alternative names of various minerals, modeling the phrasing after the *Er’ya*. In six sections, I have compiled them into one fascicle, so that those lost in confusion may find it somewhat easier to seek, and those practicing the art may recite it without difficulty. I have also included all the alternative names for ingredients used in various elixirs, listing the designations of extraordinary formulas and rare safeguards that possess methods for preparation at the forefront, while those without methods or difficult to produce are recorded afterward.

Written in the *bingxu* year of the Yuanhe era of the Tang by Mei Biao.

Collected by Mei Biao.

chunks.original_text: 右件经方，世上并有文本，或可以资经贷利，或可以养性全生。 但遇一方，并可营造。 若遍留意，其途实繁。 然此众之中，唯道有优劣，但随闲器之所入，而各寻其所好也。 故水不可以乘骏驳，陆不可以驾轻舟，稻粱菹肉，终同於饱，麻纻纨，终同於暖。 饱暖虽一，而精粗有殊。 逐甘利者，即重小丹如金。 好延生者，敬太丹似宝。 金宝之利，各齐其分，故具载於前矣。 论诸大仙丹有名无法者 黄帝九鼎丹，大仙升霞丹，紫青仙童丹，太和龙胎丹，张真人灵飞丹，太一八景丹，马明生白日升天丹，金液华丹，茅君白灵丹，白云赤雪丹，绛陵垂壁丹，七精辟恶丹，三昧消灾丹，九光神景丹，流霞鲜翠丹，舍晖吐耀丹，太清五色丹，北帝玄珠丹，神光散馥丹，凝霜积雪丹，奔星却月丹，堕月惊心丹，感灵降真丹，通神役使丹，九变丹，大还丹，九成丹，紫精丹。 按《楚泽经》已上诸丹，并是往古得道者，出世仙丹。 服之白日升天，身生羽翼，变化自在，坐有立无。 药味方法，既非尘俗所知，莫得测其至要也。 自非宿有仙骨，积代累功，梦中神受者，不可得其方法也。 石药尔雅卷下竟

The above-listed formulas, all extant in the world’s written records, may serve to secure wealth and profit or to nurture one’s nature and preserve life. Should one encounter even a single method, it may be put to use. Yet if one attends to them all, the paths are indeed manifold. Among these many, only the Dao admits of superiority and inferiority—each follows the vessel’s capacity and pursues what it favors. Thus, water is unfit for riding swift steeds, and land is unsuited to sailing light boats. Though rice, millet, pickled greens, and meat all alike satisfy hunger, and hemp, ramie, fine silk, and coarse cloth all alike provide warmth, hunger and warmth may be the same, yet refinement and coarseness differ. Those who chase sweet profit prize the Lesser Elixir as gold; those who cherish longevity revere the Greater Elixir as treasure. The value of gold and treasure is equal to one’s allotted share—hence they are all recorded above.

**On the Great Immortal Elixirs, Famed but Without Formulas:**
Yellow Emperor’s Nine-Crucible Elixir, Great Immortal Ascending-Rosy-Clouds Elixir, Purple Azure Immortal Youth Elixir, Supreme Harmony Dragon Embryo Elixir, Perfected Zhang’s Numinous Flight Elixir, Supreme One Eight-Luminaries Elixir, Ma Mingsheng’s White Sun Ascension Elixir, Golden Liquid Florescence Elixir, Lord Mao’s White Numinous Elixir, White Cloud Red Snow Elixir, Crimson Mound Hanging-Wall Elixir, Seven Essences Warding-Evil Elixir, Samādhi Disaster-Dispelling Elixir, Nine Radiance Divine Light Elixir, Flowing Rosy Fresh Verdant Elixir, Abode-Glow Casting-Radiance Elixir, Supreme Clarity Five-Colors Elixir, Northern Emperor Dark Pearl Elixir, Divine Light Scattering Fragrance Elixir, Congealed Frost Accumulated Snow Elixir, Shooting Star Moon-Repelling Elixir, Moon-Falling Heart-Alarming Elixir, Spirit-Resonant Descending Perfection Elixir, Spirit-Communing Servant-Commanding Elixir, Nine Transformations Elixir, Great Return Elixir, Ninefold Perfection Elixir, Purple Essence Elixir.

According to the *Scripture of Chu Marsh*, all the above elixirs were produced by ancient adepts who attained the Dao—transcendent elixirs of the world. Ingesting them, one ascends to heaven in broad daylight, sprouts feathered wings, and moves with unfettered transformation, sitting where one wills yet leaving no trace. Their ingredients and methods lie beyond the ken of mundane folk, and none may fathom their essential subtleties. Unless one bears innate immortal bones, has accumulated merit over generations, or receives the method in a dream from the gods, their formulas cannot be obtained.

*Shiyao Er Ya*, Scroll Three, concludes.
